intro: Phyllanthus andersonii, commonly known as the Anderson's spurge, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Africa. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers. The plant produces capsules as its fruit, which contain numerous tiny seeds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in open woodlands or along stream banks. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
